Release date | 11 October 2002 | 2 September 2005 | 26 November 2008 | 4 September 2015 |} ===''The Transporter''=== {{Main|The Transporter}} Frank Martin ([[Jason Statham]]) is a highly skilled driver known only as "The Transporter." He will transport anything, no questions asked, always on time, and he is known as the best in the business. He strictly follows three rules when transporting: Rule Number 1: "Once the deal is made, it is final", Rule Number 2: "No names", and Rule Number 3: "Never open the package." Frank inadvertently breaks his own rule, opens the package and finds a bound and gagged woman. ===''Transporter 2''=== {{Main|Transporter 2}} Frank is working as the driver/chauffeur for a wealthy family, in the United States. Martin bonds with their young son, whom he drives to school every day. When the boy is kidnapped, Frank must again take action in order to protect his young "package" and his family. Eventually, Martin unravels a scheme involving biological weapons and the nefarious Gianni Chellini. Martin is forced to remove a bomb from the bottom of his car by executing an aerial corkscrew manoeuver underneath a crane. The crane catches the bomb and Martin escapes unharmed. Frank debuts the [[Audi A8 W12]] in this film. Inspector Tarconi plays an even more prominent role in this film. It is established that he and Frank are now friends, and Tarconi goes as far as to lie to the police to cover for Frank. His cooking prowess is established as well. ===''Transporter 3''=== {{Main|Transporter 3}} Frank has been pressured into transporting Valentina ([[Natalya Rudakova]]) the kidnapped daughter of Leonid Vasilev ([[Jeroen Krabbé]]), the head of the Environmental Protection Agency for Ukraine, from [[Marseille]] through [[Stuttgart]] and [[Budapest]] until he ends up in [[Odessa]] on the [[Black Sea]]. Along the way, with the help of Inspector Tarconi ([[François Berléand]]), Frank has to contend with the people who strong armed him to take the job, agents sent by Vasilev to intercept him, and the general non-cooperation of his passenger, who he realises is the package mid-way through the film. Despite Valentina's cynical disposition and Frank's resistance to get involved, Frank and Valentina fall for each other, while escaping from one life-threatening situation after another. Martin again drives an armoured [[Audi A8 W12]] in the film, as well as a [[BMX]] bicycle. ===''The Transporter Refueled''=== {{main|The Transporter Refueled}} In May 2013, at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival]], a new reboot trilogy was announced with [[EuropaCorp]] and [[China]]'s [[Fundamental Films]] co-producing and distributing the titles.{{cite news|title='Transporter' sequels announced at Cannes Film Festival|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a483790/transporter-sequels-announced-at-cannes-film-festival.html|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=digitalspy.co.uk|date=22 May 2013}}{{cite news|title=Cannes 2013: Three New Films In The Transporter Franchise Announced|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=37600|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=empireonline.com|date=22 May 2013}} The films will likely be budgeted between $30 million to $40 million each and at least one will be shot in China.{{cite news|title=New Transporter trilogy bound for big screen with parts 4 5 and 6 announced|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/05/22/new-transporter-trilogy-bound-for-big-screen-with-parts-4-5-and-6-announced-3805144/|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=metro.co.uk|date=22 May 2013}} [[Luc Besson]] will co-finance, distribute, produce and write all the films.{{cite news|title=Sequel Bits: ‘Transformers 4’, ‘Expendables 3’, ‘Transporter 4-6’, ‘The Hobbit’, ‘Anchorman 2’, ‘Pacific Rim 2’|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/sequel-bits-transformers-4-expendables-3-transporter-4-6-the-hobbit-anchorman-2-pacific-rim-2/|accessdate=24 July 2013|newspaper=slashfilm.com|date=21 May 2013}} English actor [[Ed Skrein]] replaced Jason Statham as Frank Martin on the fourth installment of the series.{{cite news|title=Transporter 4 will star Ed Skrein in Jason Statham role|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/feb/10/transporter-4-ed-skrein-jason-statham-game-of-thrones|accessdate=15 February 2014|newspaper=theguardian.com|date=10 February 2014}} The fourth film, ''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'', was released in the United States on 4 September 2015 with [[Camille Delamarre]] directing. ==Television== ===''Transporter: The Series''=== {{Main|Transporter: The Series}} ''Transporter: The Series'' is a television series based on the Transporter films which premiered in 2012 on 11 October in Germany on RTL, and on 6 December in France on M6. [[Chris Vance (actor)|Chris Vance]] took over the role of Frank from [[Jason Statham]] and was joined by Hungarian actress [[Andrea Osvárt]], who played Carla, the leading female role in the series,{{cite news |title= Cinemax's 'Transporter' Series Casts Male & Female Leads|first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/05/cinemaxs-transporter-series-casts-male-female-lead/ |newspaper=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=20 May 2011}} starring as a former Intelligence agent who organises his missions, and French actor [[François Berléand]], the only returning actor from the film series, who reprised his role as Inspector Tarconi.{{cite news |title= 'Transporter': 'Lost's' Stephen Williams to Helm Pilot (Exclusive)|first=Lesley |last=Goldberg |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/transporter-losts-stephen-williams-helm-205186 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |location=Los Angeles, California |date=23 June 2011}} The show was initially supposed to premiere on the cable network Cinemax but Cinemax pulled out due to production problems. TNT picked up the show and aired the 12-episode first season on the TNT network. TNT also ordered a 12-episode second season which aired in the autumn of 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/miptv-transporter-series-reboot-tnt-694443 |title=MIPTV: 'Transporter' Series Reboot for TNT Heavy on Action |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=8 April 2014 |first=Scott |last=Roxborough |accessdate=21 December 2014}} ==Cast and characters== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" width=99% ! rowspan="3" width="19%" | Character ! colspan="4" align="center" | Film ! style="text-align:center;"| TV series |- ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[The Transporter]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter 2]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter 3]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[The Transporter Refueled]]'' ! align="center" width="15%" | ''[[Transporter: The Series]]'' |- |{{small|'''2002'''}} |{{small|'''2005'''}} |{{small|'''2008'''}} |{{small|'''2015'''}} |{{small|'''2012-2014'''}} |- ! Caterina Boldieu | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;" |   | colspan="1" |[[Violante Placido]] |} ==Frank Martin== {{Main | Frank Martin (Transporter) }} '''Frank Martin''' is the [[protagonist]] of the films and television series. He initially serves as a [[reluctant hero]]. He is portrayed as a former [[Special Forces]] operative who was a team leader of a search and destroy unit. His military background includes operations "in and out of" [[Lebanon]], [[Syria]] and [[Sudan]]. He retires from this after becoming fatigued and disenchanted with his superior officers. In simple terms, he got tired of seeing his best efforts turned to nothing by the same people paying him to do the job. So he puts his skills to action as a private driver for hire. ==Reception== ===Box office=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width=99% border="1" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2"| Film ! rowspan="2"| Release date ! colspan="3"| Box office gross ! colspan="2" text="wrap"| Box office ranking ! rowspan="2"| Budget ! rowspan="2"| {{nowrap|{{Abbr|Ref(s)|References}}}} |- ! {{Infobox film | name = Universal Classic Monsters | image = Universal_Classic_Monsters_logo.jpg | alt = | caption = Official franchise logo as displayed on home video releases | director = | producer = | writer = | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[Universal Pictures]] | distributor = | released = | runtime = | country = United States | language = | budget = | gross = | italic title = no }} '''Universal Classic Monsters''' is a phrase used to describe the [[Horror film|horror]], [[Fantasy film|fantasy]], [[Thriller (genre)|suspense]] and [[science fiction film|science fiction]] films made by [[Universal Pictures]] during the decades of the 1920s through the 1950s. They began with ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' and ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', both [[silent films]] starring [[Lon Chaney]]. Universal continued with [[Sound film|talkies]] including monster franchises ''[[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|Dracula]]'', ''[[Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]'', ''[[The Mummy (1932 film)|The Mummy]]'', ''[[The Invisible Man (1933 film)|The Invisible Man]]'', ''[[The Wolf Man (1941 film)|The Wolf Man]]'' and ''[[Creature from the Black Lagoon]]''. The films often featured [[Bela Lugosi]], [[Boris Karloff]] and [[Lon Chaney Jr.]] ==Original films== {{legend|#0022F8|'''Phantom of the Opera'''}} {{legend|#BF0404|'''Dracula'''}} {{legend|#36FF33|'''Frankenstein'''}} {{legend|#000000|'''Edgar Allan Poe'''}} {{legend|#F8C700|'''Mummy'''}} {{legend|#71E8F6|'''Invisible Man'''}} {{legend|#804903|'''Werewolf''' / '''Wolf Man'''}} {{legend|#EB4772|'''Paula, the Ape Woman''' / '''Gorilla Girl'''}} {{legend|#24077E|'''Inner Sanctum Mysteries'''}} {{legend|#7A889C|'''Creeper'''}} {{legend|#FF7502|'''Abbott & Costello'''}} {{legend|#21935E|'''Gill Man''' / '''Creature from the Black Lagoon'''}} {{legend|#FFFFFF|'''Other'''}} ===1920s=== [[File:Lon chaney sr.JPG|thumb|right|[[Lon Chaney]] in ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (1925)]] In 1923, Universal produced the drama ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'', starring [[Lon Chaney]] as [[Quasimodo]]. The production sets were built to evoke 15th-century Paris, including a re-creation of the [[Notre Dame de Paris]] cathedral. Chaney stars as [[Erik (The Phantom of the Opera)|The Phantom]] in 1925's horror film, ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', based on the [[The Phantom of the Opera|mystery novel]] by [[Gaston Leroux]]. The interior of the [[Opéra Garnier]] was recreated to scale and was used again in the 1943 remake with [[Claude Rains]]. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! Film ! U.S. release date ! Baklanova]], [[Cesare Gravina]], [[Stuart Holmes]], [[Samuel de Grasse]], [[George Siegmann]], [[Josephine Crowell]] |style="text-align: center;"| 100% |style="text-align: center;"| 7.8 |- | ! scope="row" | ''[[The Last Warning]]'' | January 6, 1929 | [[Laura LaPlante]], [[Montagu Love]], [[Margaret Livingston]], [[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]] | {{N/A}} |style="text-align: center;"| 7.5 |- | ! scope="row" | ''[[The Last Performance]]'' | November 1929 | [[Paul Fejos]] | [[Conrad Veidt]], [[Mary Philbin]] | {{N/A}} |style="text-align: center;"| 6.8 |- |} ===1930s=== [[File:Bela Lugosi as Dracula-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bela Lugosi]] as ''[[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|Dracula]]'']] [[File:Frankenstein's monster (Boris Karloff).jpg|right|thumb|[[Boris Karloff]] in ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'']] In 1931, [[Bela Lugosi]] starred in Universal's ''Dracula'' and [[Boris Karloff]] in ''Frankenstein''. Actors [[Dwight Frye]] and [[Edward Van Sloan]], who played major supporting roles in both films, made several film appearances in this decade. Make-up artist [[Jack Pierce (makeup artist)|Jack Pierce]] created several monsters' make-up starting in the 1930s. ''The Mummy'', starring Karloff, was produced in 1932. This was followed by a trilogy of films based on the tales of [[Edgar Allan Poe]]: ''[[Murders in the Rue Morgue (1932 film)|Murders in the Rue Morgue]]'' (1932) starring Lugosi, ''[[The Black Cat (1934 film)|The Black Cat]]'' (1934), and ''[[The Raven (1935 film)|The Raven]]'' (1935), the latter two of which teamed Lugosi with Karloff. Universal began releasing sequels including ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'' (1935), ''[[Dracula's Daughter]]'' (1936) and sequels for ''[[The Invisible Man (1933 film)|The Invisible Man]]'' (1933). The first mainstream werewolf picture, ''[[Werewolf of London]]'' (1935) starring [[Henry Hull]], was not a box office triumph despite being revered by audiences today. The end of Universal’s first run of horror films came in 1936. The monster movies were dropped from the production schedule altogether and would not re-emerge for another three years. In the meantime, a theatre owner revived ''Dracula'' and ''Frankenstein'' as a resoundingly successful double feature, prompting the studio to re-release the original movies. ''[[Son of Frankenstein]]'' (1939), starring [[Basil Rathbone]], Boris Karloff, and Bela Lugosi, was filmed as a result of the unexpected resurgence. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! Film ! Carroll]], [[Miles Mander]], [[Lionel Belmore]], [[Rose Hobart]] | {{N/A}} |style="text-align: center;"| 6.7 |- |} ===1940s=== During the 1940s, Universal released ''The Wolf Man'' (1941), with [[Lon Chaney Jr.]] The junior Chaney became the studio's leading monster movie actor in the 1940s, just as his father had been two decades earlier, supplanting the 1930s' Karloff and Lugosi by a wide margin in terms of the number of leading roles that he played. Chaney Jr. physically resembled his father apart from usually being somewhat overweight, which the senior Chaney never was. The studio dropped the "Jr." from the junior Chaney's billing almost immediately to confuse some in the audiences into assuming that this was the same actor. In 1943, the studio created a remake of ''[[Phantom of the Opera (1943 film)|Phantom of the Opera]]'', this time starring [[Nelson Eddy]] and [[Susanna Foster]] with Claude Rains as the Phantom. The ''Frankenstein'' and ''Wolf Man'' series continued with ''[[The Ghost of Frankenstein]]'' (1942), in which Chaney Jr. played Frankenstein's monster and Lugosi reprised his role as Ygor, and ''Frankenstein Meets the Wolf Man'' (1943) with Lugosi as the Frankenstein monster and Chaney Jr. as the Wolf Man. ''Son of Dracula'' (1943) featured Chaney Jr. in Lugosi's original role as the Count. The ''Mummy'' series was also continued with ''[[The Mummy's Hand]]'' (1940), ''[[The Mummy's Tomb]]'' (1942), ''[[The Mummy's Ghost]]'' and ''[[The Mummy's Curse]]'' (both 1944) with Chaney Jr. as the Mummy in the last three films. ''[[House of Frankenstein (1944 film)|House of Frankenstein]]'' (1944) and ''[[House of Dracula]]'' (1945) featured many of the monsters from the studio's previous films. As the decade drew to a close, the comedy ''[[Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein]]'' (1948) features Lugosi in only his second film as [[Count Dracula]], alongside Chaney Jr. as [[Larry Talbot]] (the Wolf Man), and [[Glenn Strange]] as [[Frankenstein's monster]]. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! ''Creature from the Black Lagoon'', directed by [[Jack Arnold (director)|Jack Arnold]], was released in 1954. ''Dracula'' and ''Frankenstein'' were re-released as double features in theatres, and were later broadcast in syndication on American television in 1957 as part of the ''[[Shock Theater]]'' package of Universal Monster Movies.{{cite book|last = Okuda|first = Ted|authorlink = Ted Okuda|author2=Yurkiw, Mark |title = Chicago TV Horror Movie Shows: From Shock Theatre to Svengoolie|publisher = Lake Claremont Press|year = 2007|page = 14|isbn = 978-1893121133|quote= The 'Shock!' package was sold in 142 markets. As a result, stations across the country aired a late-night ''Shock Theatre'' series to showcase these pictures.}} Magazines such as ''[[Famous Monsters of Filmland]]'' covered the monster films. Universal spent the last half of the decade issuing a number of one-shot monster films. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! ! Film ! U.S. release date ! Director(s) ! Cast ! scope="row" | ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' | June 9, 2017 | [[Alex Kurtzman]] | [[Tom Cruise]] |style="text-align: center;"| 15% |style="text-align: center;"| 5.5 |- |} ===Dark Universe=== [[File:Dark Universe official logo.jpg|thumb|242x242px|Official logo of the Dark Universe, shared film universe as released by Universal Pictures]] Dark Universe is the term given by Universal Pictures to their planned [[cinematic universe]], which will be based on the classic Universal Monsters film series. The studio's first attempt at this universe was with the film ''[[Dracula Untold]]''. Released on October 10, 2014, with [[Luke Evans (actor)|Luke Evans]] in the [[Count Dracula|titular role]], the film was developed prior to plans for a shared universe of horror films. However, it was retooled to be a part of the franchise. The film's mixed financial and critical reception resulted in the film's future status within the franchise becoming uncertain. Since the release of ''Dracula Untold'', the connections to the shared universe have been downplayed. Universal, which had announced plans to reboot [[The Mummy (franchise)|''The Mummy'' franchise]] in 2012, decided to re-position the new installment as the first film in the series. ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' was set to be released in 2017 with [[Alex Kurtzman]] as director.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Universal Stakes Out Release Date for Third Monster Movie|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|accessdate=September 24, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=What Universal Must Do To Sell Its Classic Monsters Universe|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#7772cec46b38|accessdate=September 24, 2016|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=July 13, 2016}} Also, Kurtzman and [[Chris Morgan (writer)|Chris Morgan]] were announced as headlining the Dark Universe, with collaborations from [[David Koepp]] and [[Christopher McQuarrie]].{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-may-1495481404-htmlstory.html|title=Universal debuts its spooky new Dark Universe and its upcoming 'Bride of Frankenstein'|publisher=''LA Times''|author=Woerner, Meredith|date=May 22, 2017}} Along with the crew, Universal announced the casting of [[Russell Crowe]] as [[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (character)|Dr. Henry Jekyll / Mr. Edward Hyde]], [[Javier Bardem]] as the [[Frankenstein's monster|Frankenstein Monster]], and [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Griffin (The Invisible Man)|The Invisible Man]]. They would join [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Sofia Boutella]], as Nick Morton and Princess Ahmanet / The Mummy. [[Bill Condon]] was announced as the director of the franchise's ''[[Bride of Frankenstein]]'', originally set to be released on February 14, 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2423971/its-been-one-year-since-the-dark-universe-was-announced-so-what-happened|title=It's Been One Year Since The Dark Universe Was Announced, So What Happened?|publisher=Cinema Blend|author=Holmes, Adam|date=May 2018}} Even though various sources claimed that Evans' character might have at least a cameo in ''The Mummy'' or any of the upcoming films in the universe, Kurtzman denied these claims, stating that he considered the film to not be a part of the ''Dark Universe''.{{cite web|last=Trumbore |first=Dave |date=December 4, 2016 |title='The Mummy': Alex Kurtzman Confirms 'Dracula Untold' Is Not Canon, Teases Jekyll's Role |url=http://collider.com/the-mummy-universal-monsters-shared-universe/#dracula-untold |publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] }} Additional rebooted versions of their characters were announced to have films in development as well including: the [[The Wolf Man (1941 film)|Wolf Man]], the [[Creature from the Black Lagoon]], the [[Phantom of the Opera (1943 film)|Phantom of the Opera]], and [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]]. The shared film universe's official theme music was composed by [[Danny Elfman]]. On June 9, 2017, ''[[The Mummy (2017 film)|The Mummy]]'' was released.{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Universal Stakes Out Release Date for Third Monster Movie|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|accessdate=September 24, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=May 3, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011035549/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-stakes-release-date-third-890292|archivedate=October 11, 2016|df=}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=What Universal Must Do To Sell Its Classic Monsters Universe|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#b89e3026b382|accessdate=September 24, 2016|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=July 13, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927142045/http://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2016/07/13/what-universal-must-do-to-sell-its-classic-monsters-universe/#b89e3026b382|archivedate=September 27, 2016|df=}}{{cite web |last=Armitage |first=Hugh |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/the-mummy/news/a830407/the-mummy-brendan-fraser-easter-eggs/ |title=Exclusive: Why ''The Mummy'' needed Brendan Fraser trilogy Easter eggs, according to director Alex Kurtzman |publisher=Digitalspy.com |date=June 10, 2017 |accessdate=July 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170626182450/http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/the-mummy/news/a830407/the-mummy-brendan-fraser-easter-eggs/ |archivedate=June 26, 2017 |df= }} The film received generally negative reviews from critics, and performed below the studio's expectations at the box office.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/the-mummy-reviews-roundup-1202457392/|title=‘The Mummy’ Reviews: What the Critics Are Saying|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 8, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607223217/http://variety.com/2017/film/news/the-mummy-reviews-roundup-1202457392/|archivedate=June 7, 2017|df=}} By November, ''The Bride of Frankenstein'' was pulled from its initial release, and lead producers/co-architects of the Dark Universe, [[Alex Kurtzman]] and [[Chris Morgan (writer)|Chris Morgan]], left Universal and departed from the franchise. Universal has put a hold on future projects while they create a plan for future releases.{{Cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/alex-kurtzman-chris-morgan-exit-universal-monsterverse-1055854 |title=Universal's 'Monsterverse' in Peril as Top Producers Exit (Exclusive) |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]] |date=November 8, 2017}} [[Universal Pictures]] released an official statement reading: {{Quote|After thoughtful consideration, Universal Pictures and director [[Bill Condon]] have decided to postpone ''Bride of Frankenstein''. None of us want[s] to move too quickly to meet a release date when we know this special movie needs more time to come together. Bill is a director whose enormous talent has been proven time and again, and we all look forward to continuing to work on this film together.{{Cite news|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/uk/movies/the-mummy/53302/dark-universe-the-undignified-death-of-a-cinematic-universe|title=Dark Universe: the undignified death of a cinematic universe|work=Den of Geek|access-date=November 15, 2017|language=en}}}} By January 2018, development on the film progressed with Condon hiring a production team consisting of cinematographer [[Tobias A. Schliessler]], production designer [[Sarah Greenwood]], composer [[Carter Burwell]], and costume designer [[Jacqueline Durran]].{{cite web|last=Marc|first=Christopher|url=http://omegaunderground.com/2018/01/15/bill-condons-bride-frankenstein-assembles-production-team-will-shoot/|title=''Bride of Frankenstein'' Assembles Production Team - When Will It Shoot?|date=January 15, 2018|publisher=''Omega Underground''|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} In May of the same year, artist Robert Vargas announced from his social media account that he had attended a meeting with the studio and will collaborate on the Dark Universe films moving forward.{{cite web|last=Schaefer|first=Sandy|url=https://screenrant.com/dark-universe-monster-movies/|title=Universal's Dark Universe Might Not Be Dead After All|date=May 18, 2018|publisher=''ScreenRant''|accessdate=May 18, 2018}} Successful horror film producer [[Jason Blum]] has publicly expressed his interest in working on the Dark Universe franchise.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbr.com/jason-blum-dark-universe-interest/|title=Spawn Producer Jason Blum Interested In Reviving Dark Universe|date=18 August 2018|publisher=}} ==See also== *''[[The Monster Squad]]'' (1987) '''Animation''' *''[[Monster Force]]'' (1994) (TV series) *''[[Van Helsing: The London Assignment]]'' (2004) (DTV) *''[[The Mummy (TV series)|The Mummy: The Animated Series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Neibaur |first=James L. |title=The Monster Movies of Universal Studios |date=2017 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-1-44-227817-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-YrDgAAQBAJ}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Universal Monsters film series}} * [http://www.darkuniverse.com/ Dark Universe homepage] {{Universal Monsters}} [[Category:Film series introduced in 1923]] [[Category:Universal Studios]] [[Category:Universal Classic Monsters]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Horror film characters]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Fiction about monsters]]

{{redirect|Wet Paint|the 1966 silent film|Wet Paint (film)|the 1946 Disney film|Wet Paint (1946 film)}} {{infobox company | logo = Wetpaint-logo-2015.png | type = Subsidiary | foundation = October 2005 | location = New York City, U.S. | num_employees = 65 | industry = Internet technology (2006–present) | products = Technology platforms for the media industry; formerly wiki hosting | revenue = Venture capital funded | owner = Function(X) | homepage = [http://www.wetpaint.com/ www.wetpaint.com]}}
'''Wetpaint''' is an internet company and a wholly owned subsidiary of Function(X). Founded in 2005, Wetpaint both publishes the website Wetpaint Entertainment, focused on entertainment news, and develops a proprietary technology platform, the Social Distribution System, that is used to provide analytics for its own website as well as other online publishers'. Wetpaint began as a [[wiki farm]], hosting [[wiki]]s using its own proprietary software, before moving into hosting of professional content in 2010. Wetpaint's wiki-hosting component was spun off completely in 2013 after being purchased by Wikifoundry.<ref>{{cite | url = http://www.wikifoundrycentral.com/thread/5139827/Wet+Paint+Wiki | title = Wet Paint Wiki - WikiFoundry Central | date = 2013-09-01 | access-date = 2017-10-25 }}</ref>
== History == Wetpaint was originally called Wikisphere, and begun as a [[wiki farm]], hosting [[wiki]]s using proprietary software. It was co-founded in October 2005 by Ben Elowitz, who had previously co-founded the online jewelry retailer [[Blue Nile Inc.]] In December 2005, the company and site were renamed to Wetpaint.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://blog.seattlepi.com/venture/archives/100675.asp | title = Startup Wikisphere changes its name to Wetpaint | publisher = Seattle Post-Intelligencer | date = 2005-12-01 }}</ref> In October 2005, the company received its initial A round of venture capital funding of USD5.25 million from Trinity Ventures and Frazier Technology Ventures.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/business/246734_wiki02.html | title = Startup Wikisphere raises $5.25 million in 1st round | publisher = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date = 2005-11-02 | first1=John | last1=Cook}}</ref> Wetpaint closed a USD9.5 million 'B' round of funding in January 2007, adding [[Accel Partners]] to the list of investors.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.redherring.com/Article.aspx?a=21412&hed=Wiki+Providers+Score+Funding&sector=Industries&subsector=InternetAndServices | title = Wiki Providers Score Funding | publisher = [[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]] | date = 2007-02-22 }}</ref> Wetpaint closed a Series C round of venture capital funding of USD25 million in May 2008. Investors included Accel Partners, Trinity Ventures, and Frazier Technology Ventures.
Wetpaint was named by ''[[Time Magazine]]'' as one of the 50 Best Websites of 2007.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1633488_1633608_1633634,00.html | title = Wetpaint.com - 50 Best Websites 2007 | publisher = [[Time Magazine]] | date = 2007-07-09 }}</ref>
In March 2008, Wetpaint added [[social networking]] features.<ref>{{cite news | title = Wetpaint Goes Social | url = http://press.wetpaint.com/page/Wetpaint+Goes+Social | work = press release | publisher = Wetpaint | date = 2008-03-10 | accessdate = 2008-05-11 }}</ref>
In July 2009, Wetpaint laid off 15 of their 56 employees.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.xconomy.com/seattle/2009/07/27/seattle-layoff-update-targeted-genetics-wetpaint-google-and-others-cut-staff/ | title = Seattle Layoff Update:Targeted Genetics, Wetpaint, Google, and Others Cut Staff | publisher = xconomy | date = 2009-08-26 }}</ref> An additional 9 employees, including co-founders Kevin Flaherty and Alex Berg, were laid off in December.<ref name="cuts staff">{{cite news | url = http://www.techflash.com/seattle/2009/12/exclusive_wetpaint_cuts_staff_changes_focus_to_online_publishing.html | title = Exclusive: Wetpaint cuts staff, changes focus to publishing | publisher = John Cook, TechFlash | date = 2009-12-04 }}</ref> The company also decided to refocus the website on professionally created content. Both steps were taken as a result of declining online ad revenue.<ref name="cuts staff" />
During late 2009, Wetpaint re-launched its main homepage, at wetpaint.com, as the Wetpaint Entertainment platform, a set of new online TV fan destination sites, geared toward the female 18-34 demographic.<ref>[http://www.thestreet.com/story/10852711/wetpaint-launches-online-tv-fan-destination-with-coverage-of-this-falls-most-anticipated-tv-programs.html Wetpaint Launches Online TV Fan Destination With Coverage Of This Fall's Most Anticipated TV Programs]</ref> The wiki farm was renamed "Wikis by Wetpaint", and was moved to the domain wetpaintcentral.com.
In December 2010, the company announced the Wetpaint Social Distribution System.<ref name="prweb.com">{{cite news|title=Wetpaint Entertainment Rapidly Becomes a Leading Online Entertainment News Source Due to Wetpaint’s Proprietary Social Distribution System|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/12/prweb9044567.htm}}</ref>
In December 2012, Wetpaint was acquired by Viggle,<ref>{{cite news | url = https://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20131216-907355.html | title = Viggle Acquires Wetpaint | publisher = Press Release | date = 2013-12-16 }}</ref> an entertainment rewards platform, which was shortly renamed to its former name, Function(X).
